articles.headline: In Wild Swing, Stocks Give Up Rate-Cut Gains
articles.snippet: Many investors appeared to have second thoughts about their first reaction to the Fed’s move to lower rates.
articles.abstract: Many investors appeared to have second thoughts about their first reaction to the Fed’s move to lower rates.
articles.lead_paragraph: A day that dawned bleakly on Wall Street turned even darker late yesterday as an afternoon sell-off sent the Dow Jones industrial average down more than 360 points, or 2.6 percent. Investors worried that Citigroup’s woes might be worsening and that consumers would not spend freely this holiday shopping season.

articles.headline: Job Cuts at Chrysler Go Even Deeper Than Expected
articles.snippet: Thursday’s cuts, together with a previously announced elimination of 13,000 positions, represent a 30 percent reduction in Chrysler’s 2006 work force.
articles.abstract: Thursday’s cuts, together with a previously announced elimination of 13,000 positions, represent a 30 percent reduction in Chrysler’s 2006 work force.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, Nov. 1 — Over the last two years, the three American auto companies have vowed that their plans to slash nearly 80,000 jobs and close more than two dozen plants would be enough to transform them into leaner and nimbler competitors.

articles.headline: A Bitter Rift When a Boss Is the Buyer
articles.snippet: An internal battle at Affiliated Computer Services highlights the tensions that can occur when a founder or chief executive leads a deal to acquire a company.
articles.abstract: An internal battle at Affiliated Computer Services highlights the tensions that can occur when a founder or chief executive leads a deal to acquire a company.
articles.lead_paragraph: “We could fire you and the entire management team,” the five directors wrote, “but that would not help our shareholders, customers or employees.”
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Obama Envisions New Iran Approach
articles.snippet: In an interview, Senator Barack Obama said that forging a new relationship with Iran would be part of his effort to stabilize Iraq.
articles.abstract: In an interview, Senator Barack Obama said that forging a new relationship with Iran would be part of his effort to stabilize Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Oct. 31 — Senator Barack Obama says he would “engage in aggressive personal diplomacy” with Iran if elected president and would offer economic inducements and a possible promise not to seek “regime change” if Iran stopped meddling in Iraq and cooperated on terrorism and nuclear issues.
articles.byline: By Michael R. Gordon and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: A Modern Marketplace for Israel’s Ultra-Orthodox
articles.snippet: The Israeli economy has adjusted in surprising ways to the market power of the ultra-Orthodox community.
articles.abstract: The Israeli economy has adjusted in surprising ways to the market power of the ultra-Orthodox community.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIT SHEMESH, Israel — When Larry Pinczower switches on his cellphone, the seal of a rabbinate council appears. Unable to send text messages, take photographs or connect to the Internet, his phone is a religiously approved adaptation to modernity by the ultra-Orthodox sector of Israeli life.

articles.headline: Effort to Save Everglades Falters as Funds Drop
articles.snippet: Seven years into an $8 billion effort to rescue the Florida Everglades, federal financing has slowed to a trickle.
articles.abstract: Seven years into an $8 billion effort to rescue the Florida Everglades, federal financing has slowed to a trickle.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI, Oct. 31 — The rescue of the Florida Everglades, the largest and most expensive environmental restoration project on the planet, is faltering.

articles.headline: Tapped Out, but Hopeful: A Break in Texas’s Oil Decline
articles.snippet: As oil approaches $100 a barrel, there is plenty of incentive to find more American oil, but even with new investment, the nation’s oil fields are mostly tapped out.
articles.abstract: As oil approaches $100 a barrel, there is plenty of incentive to find more American oil, but even with new investment, the nation’s oil fields are mostly tapped out.
articles.lead_paragraph: CRANE, Texas — The North McElroy oil field here in West Texas has long been a tableau of rusty tanks and worn-out pump jacks. “Not in Use” is painted across broken electrical panels affixed to an abandoned building.

articles.headline: Being Kept in the Dark on Wall Street
articles.snippet: Every financial disaster deserves a scapegoat.  This time it could be the credit rating agencies.
articles.abstract: Every financial disaster deserves a scapegoat.  This time it could be the credit rating agencies.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s time for sunlight on Wall Street.

articles.headline: Militants Draw New Front Line Inside Pakistan
articles.snippet: For the first time, heavy fighting has moved beyond Pakistan’s tribal fringe and into more settled areas.
articles.abstract: For the first time, heavy fighting has moved beyond Pakistan’s tribal fringe and into more settled areas.
articles.lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan, Nov. 1 — For much of the last century, the mountainous region of Swat was ruled as a princely kingdom where a benign autocrat, the wali, bestowed schools for girls, health care for everyone and the chance to get a degree abroad for the talented.
